Turing Award 1968

Winner: Richard Hamming

Why the Turing Award?

Richard Hamming is the third person in the world that received the prestigious Turing Award. He is well known for the many implication that his work had on computer engineering, such as the Hamming code, the Hamming numbers , the Hamming window and the Hamming distance. In particular, the reason he won is "for his work on numerical methods, automatic coding systems, and error-detecting and error-correcting codes".

More on his work

Hamming code

The Hamming codes are basically linear-correcting codes, that can detect one-bit and two-bit errors. Hamming invented them in order to automatically correct errors introduced by punched cards readers (in fact, they can also correct one-bit errors without detection of uncorrected errors). Before the invention of Hamming code , there already were some simple error-detecting codes (e.g. parity bit ), but no one ever reached this efficiency before.

Hamming numbers

More generally called Regular numbers , the Hamming numbers are those numbers that evenly divide powers of 60, and equivantly their only prime divisors are 2,3 and 5.

In computer science they are known as Hamming numbers since Richard Hamming invented the Hamming problem , that consist in finding algorithms that could generate these numbers in ascending order.

Hamming distance

The Hamming distance is an important concept in terms of error detection and error correction. In practice, the minimum Hamming distance is the minimum numbers of bits of a codeword that you should flip to obtain another determined codeword. (E.g. if you have the codewords "000" and "111" the Hamming distance is 3, because you would need to flip all the three bits of the first one to obtain the second one).
